title: Friday, 4th January 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Here we go again. Morning. Hi. Welcome. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever with the etc.

Soundbuy Morning.........what have I missed?

You seen this? https://www.ft.com...-a3aa-118c761d2745

Tom Dalgleish BE, You need an MC
Blank canvas Bolivian equities for everyone?
11:04 am
BE11:05am

The FT has, internally, run an annual stock picking thingmy for several years. Sometimes involving sweepstake type cash but usually not.

GBKrona Good morning!
Tom Dalgleish AAPL to bounce?
BE11:06am

Want a go? Well, you can. Here: https://survey.ft....SV_7X9MQVLeCx6BpQN

BE11:07am

I've no idea how robust that system is, nor how easy it is to game. Generally speaking, these types of things are often won by the people who find legitimate ways to cheat.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Which makes it a fair representation of the actual market, one could argue.

BE11:08am

Anyway, FT staffers playing this year kicking in a donation to Habitat for Humanity and I suggest you do the same: https://www.ft.com/ft-seasonal-appeal

Manxish Morning everyone, Happy Friday
undefined
11:08 am
BE11:09am

Okay, where do we start?

VV75 morning
Tom Dalgleish Iff Apple cuts prices to gain share then its suppliers will be big winners
FATDAZ Morning all
BornCynic Morning
BE11:10am

China's cut the RRR and scheduled talks for Monday with whoever currently runs the US, so we're up. FTSE ahead 1.2pc at pixel.

FATDAZ @Tom D cant see it doing that I am afraid but may be some cheaper entry level devices say chrome book like phones that don't need high[power processors just good connections
BE11:11am

And we do, as far as I know, have US payrolls later. The government shutdown didn't remove that from the diary.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

But the ROTR have already moved on to Apple. Fair enough I guess. There's not nearly enough written about Apple.

BE11:13am

What the world needs now, to paraphrase Jackie DeShannon, is more opinions on Apple.

FATDAZ @BE I'm I the only one that thinks it odd the leader of the free world is using tactics that one might readily associate with a despot in the developing world ?
BornCynic "Wagamama turnover rises 15.4% in second quarter" not surprised - there was a queue to get into the Canterbury one over Xmas.
BE11:14am

Shares up 1.8pc premarket.

casapinos @BE i'd rather have "love sweet love...."
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Lots of people made the point yesterday that demand for a high-end smartphone is a pretty weird proxy for the Chinese economy ......

Blackbag99 I like the wagamama story, the food is good, the delivery might be interesting for the future
BE11:16am

.... and we had a bit of a waffle about how Chinese smartphone demand isn't even a good proxy for worldwide smartphone demand, because of WeChat.

BE11:17am

And of course, if it's an Apple problem rather than a macro problem, it might be within the company's control to fix.

JimboRock Regards wagamama, I wouldn't fancy racing over London's many speedbumps with 4 Ramens to go
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Nomura reckons part-exchange is the way to go.

BE11:18am

With Oct-Dec shipments seemingly having abruptly fallen by about 10%, we do not think the weakness can be explained by Chinese macroeconomic factors alone, as China accounted for roughly 25% of iPhone sales volume in 2017. We think the downward revisions also reflect sales declines unrelated to China or to US-China trade frictions.
We estimate that the iPhone accounts for roughly 6% of sales in Japan's electronic parts industry (and that Apple overall accounts for 8-9%), so a slump in iPhone sales is bad news for the industry. We expect some short-term earnings impact from iPhone-specific parts in particular (parts for the camera, display, and wireless portions), as production capacity for such parts cannot be quickly shifted over to production for other clients. As one possible solution for the sales shortfall, Apple has said that it intends to enhance its trade-in program (which it had previously justified as an environmentally conscious effort). As a medium-term impact, we would expect expansion in recycling business involving used iPhones and an extension of the overall iPhone life cycle. We think this could provide new business opportunities for companies producing consumable supplies and companies involved in the recycling ecosystem (through batteries and other products).

JimboRock Oh anything on Schroders please?
Tom Dalgleish BE, isnt that another name for a price cut
undefined
11:19 am
BE11:19am

@JimboRock: Schroders is Exane I think.

Schroders PLC (SDR:LSE): Last: 2,535, up 96 (+3.94%), High: 2,540, Low: 2,470, Volume: 145.82k
DJ truly joyous timing from Peel Hunt yesterday:"JD, Joules, boohoo and G4M look safe havens"
BE11:21am

Arnaud Giblat etc have a big thing out on the asset managers for 2019. Schroders moves up to "outperform" in that.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

(@FATDAZ: sorry, bud, I can't have cut and paste stuff in the comments.)

BE11:22am

Schroders remains the most diversified and highest quality asset manager in our coverage, yet for the first time in years it trades at 12x PE/19e, in line with UK peers on fresh numbers. Schroders is enjoying healthy growth in UK Wealth and management has been willing and able to do bolt-on deals. Also, 2020 will see the benefits of the Lloyds assets (+4% to EPS).

Tom Dalgleish In hindsight, peak Apple had to be the opening of Apple Park. Vanity begets hubris and downfall
chopper bear this made me chuckle _ todd kozel ex ceo of gkp arrested before xmas for fraud and money laundering
BE11:22am

Top sector pick is Amundi.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We expect no retail flows in Q4, which is better than at most listed peers. While this is far off the greater than 10% inflow rate achieved between 4Q16 and 1Q18, the rotation of euro accounts into unit-linked, the French fiscal reforms and the lowest cost base in the industry provide structural reasons for best-in-class growth. While earnings cuts are not a reason to cheer, we have cut 2019e EPS by an aggregate ~6% since 1 October whereas the shares lost 30% over the period: the stock has traded with a beta far too high.

BE11:22am

And they're not keen on Man.

BE11:23am

Man Group remains one of our least preferred stocks with negative operating leverage among the most acute within our asset management coverage. This will likely compound the reduced appetite for HF assets and the negative mix shift in fees. Although we expect Q4 results (1st March) to be a key negative catalyst we also note a good bounce in AHL performance in December 2018.

11:22 am
Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 136.15, up 1.7 (+1.26%), High: 136.30, Low: 133.15, Volume: 844.42k
FATDAZ @DJ re Joules and that whole lifestyle clothing space here is the issue summed up in one link http://www.bondstreetchelmsford.co.uk/index.php/shops

Wagamama mentioned several times on the right.

So the bondholder report revealed LFL sales were up 12% in the 12 weeks to 11 November

chopper bear yes a.m
rw42 Wagamama's takeaway worked fine even with soups - plastic containers with tight lids. And now i'm hungry..
A. M. @Chopper: shady dealings in KRG? well I never..

Margins squeaked up 50bp over the 12 weeks but were down by the same amount over the 28 weeks.

DJ @FATDAZ G4M -50% this morning
Blank canvas Fatdaz: your research note was interesting and it disappeared as i was reading it. (BE rules here). Can you summarise it, or post a link
FATDAZ @DJ not one I follow but thanks

How can Wagamama keep doing double-digit LFL? Dunno.

FATDAZ @blank canvass will do
11:29 am
BE11:29am

How much of the LFL was on price hikes and menu engineering, which anecdotally at least seem to have been a feature in the fourth quarter? Dunno.

FATDAZ @Blank Canvass https://www.researchgate.net/publication/303696398_JP_Morgan_-_Eye_on_the_Market_the_Agony_and_the_Ecstacy
BE11:29am

What happens when the growth tails off? Well, Restaurant Group risks becoming a value trap again. Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:29am

Within the cost breakdown, rent cost inflation has slowed, which means labour costs (not disclosed) must be continuing to rise quickly given that costs per outlet rose by 8%, in line with average sales per outlet over the 28-week period.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Part of the margin pressure may be due to delivery accounting for an even share of the LFL sales growth (alongside in-store volume and price growth). We believe higher delivery sales have yet to bring lower labour utilisation.

Blank canvas thanks Fatdaz. much appreciated
cracklenpop Retailers lower - Jefferies cutting forecasts, apparently.
BE11:30am

We forecast -1.4% LFL sales for RTN in 2018E (vs -2.2% after 42 weeks), assisted by strong Q4 footfall growth in cinemas and airports, resulting in November YTD growth of 5.1% and 3.3%, respectively. These trends should have assisted these parts of RTN’s estate, while the pubs, in line with much of the sector, should have traded well in December, reflecting strong Christmas bookings, the timing of Christmas Day (on a Tuesday) and unseasonally warm weather (vs two weeks of snow in December 2017).

FATDAZ @Blank canvass my quote is from page 23 on the pDF page 20 in the document index
BE11:30am

In our view, RTN’s valuation is fair given that there is a lot for the company to prove. The challenges facing the company and its forecasts include maintaining all expansion and synergy targets whilst trying to: maintain Wagamama LFL sales growth; turn around Frankie & Benny’s, Coast to Coast and Chiquito; and slow the rapid pace of cost inflation at Wagamama.

JimboRock @rw42 - the delivery guys near me are all ex-speedway or perhaps future champions
FATDAZ Everyone should read that document IMHO
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Numis more optimistic.

BE11:31am

Although the acquisition has only just closed, we are
encouraged by the run rate of growth into CY19. We currently model 8% growth in lfls for Wagamama this year and EBIT margin +60bp (inclusive of synergies). We see upside to the former assumption, compared to the 4y average lfl growth of 10% and given the reopening of several recently refurbished flagship sites. RTN is likely to publish a post-close update at the end of January, which we expect to show that lfls in the legacy business remained in growth. The prospectus disclosed lfl growth of 1.4% for the 14-week period following the end of the FIFA World Cup.

BE11:31am

We view RTN as attractively valued on a FY19 P/E of 10.9x and EV/EBITDA of 6.8x. See our note from 11th December for more detailed analysis of the Wagamama acquisition and estimate changes following the deal. In short, we believe the current share price is supported by the value in Wagamama and the 130 concession and pub restaurant sites, which leaves the 381 Leisure sites (making £60m of outlet-level EBITDA) trading at less than 2x EBITDA.

11:31 am
undefined
nichoman GKP is one my top 5 picks for 2019 !

@Fatdaz, apologies, but we can't have slabs of text appearing in the comments for two reasons.

11:33 am

You can argue that Celgene was more distressed than the average biotech, as two-thirds of its revenue comes from a drug whose patent protection expires very shortly.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So it was already trading at distress levels.

jaws IBT TRUST hold 8 or 9 % of that Celgene.

Should we expect a wave of consolidation to follow? Depends who you ask.

BE11:38am

Predictably, this is what you get if yo ask Goldman:

11:38 am
BE11:38am

[W]e expect to see a step up in biopharma M&A activity in 2019. Unlike last year, 2019 kicked off with a large deal in spite of recent market volatility, and we now expect the debate to pivot to: (1) whether the proposed acquisition of CELG by BMY will prove to be idiosyncratic or the beginning of a broader trend, and (2) whether there will be additional larger scale deals or only bolt-on deals (as seen in recent prior years.

FATDAZ Hard to imagine a $40 bln market cap company (pre bid) in distress
BE11:39am

Which is on the back of the 11th annual Goldman Sachs CEOs Unscripted Conference, where CEOs said lots of things that frankly may as well have been scripted.

Potter what's going on with gear4music?
BE11:40am

nThe GS banking panel indicated that in general M&A was robust in 2018 (aside from biotech) and they are optimistic for M&A to continue in 2019 given that the key drivers still exist. While they did not rule out additional transformative M&A this year, the panelists noted that market volatility can create an unfavorable environment for deals as it could take time for a board to accept that a lower valuation represents a new norm vs. prior recent highs and hence it will be interesting to see how this evolves into 1Q19. However, the bigger strategic question on many biopharma CEOs’ and boards’ minds is drug pricing dynamics, which our panelists noted was a source of anxiety and was weighing on CEO confidence, particularly for potential acquisitions of companies in price sensitive categories; highly innovative, next-generation oncology, and rare disease drugs are possible exceptions given better pricing leverage.

Blackbag99 OK, I think wagamama might give some rest bite to some of the tired tex/mex/americana. Might be worth some more time for me.
FATDAZ Pharmaceuticals not my area of expertise any thought on pipeline of big pharma and prospects for new new genomic related drugs/ treatments that seem to be getting lots of headlines right now?
11:40 am
BE11:41am

Easy capital might be drying up, Chinese buyers might be disappearing, that kind of thing ......

BE11:41am

In terms of the specifics:

BE11:41am

PFE’s new CEO said big deals are off the table for them and instead sees greater appetite for bolt-on deals. For context, we’d note that PFE has previously characterized large deals as greater than $60bn (per the 3Q18 earnings call); further, given its cash position, we think a bolt-on deal for PFE could be up to the $10-15bn+ range, but the majority of bolt-on biopharma deals are likely to be considerably less than that, consistent with historical trends. ALXN said it will continue its disciplined approach to BD as it looks to broaden its pipeline. INCY also expressed interest in BD, specifically in late-stage commercial assets that are accretive to revenue and earnings. Further, in response to a question on whether it is vulnerable to M&A, INCY said that while its focus is on creating an innovative company that develops its own products, it also noted they are ultimately answerable to shareholders.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

What CEOs say publicly about M&A has been a pretty unreliable way to predict what companies do about M&A, of course.

BE11:43am

Back to Goldman:

Viking1 JP Morgan health care conference starts this Monday in SF.Plenty of M&A rumours I suspect

Due to a "near-mid term cash flow mis-balance", in the sense that it's going to burn more than $15bn over the next three years.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Whilst AZN have managed to plug the cash flow hole over the last few years by a mix of debt raising and cash generation via externalisation/OOI, we see increased risk that AZN might be forced to think about a cash flow accretive transaction (especially if there are any material pipeline disappointments) to balance the near-mid term cash imbalances.

BE11:48am

Oh, and just before we move on from Celgene .....

BE11:49am

.... Baird saying the discount's far too wide.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

We believe CELG at $81 doesn't make sense when this deal is probably going to close in the mid-to-high $90s. We think the market is pricing in 35-45% probability of it falling through and CELG going back to the $60s. We are more bullish on the probability of the deal and the downside for CELG shares if it falls through, seeing as management is now shown to be willing sellers.

BE11:50am

To remind, BMS is paying $50 cash per share plus one share.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

All in, CELG shares should close at around $100, in our view, if this transaction goes through. Even without a CVR value and an additional 10% slippage to BMY gets $90 vs. a stock at $81, a $9 discount

VV75 @Fatdaz, it's a cvr and quite common in biotech takeovers, usually tied to certain approvals for medicines in the pipeline.
BornCynic Met the UK intenal auditor of BMY in the 90's. She was picked up by the BMY driver (hat and everything.....). Those were the days of endless money.....
11:58 am
BE11:59am

Black Friday discounting and warehouse problems get the blame

BE11:59am

Meaning gross margin targets are reset.

BE12:00pm

Peel Hunt -- house broker -- needless to say -- says:

FATDAZ @VV75 thanks wouldn't be a bad idea if that was extended to other areas of M&A activity I feel :)
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The outcome in H2 in terms of gross margin decline (160 bps) won’t be as bad as in H1 (230 bps), but the absolute gross margin is now 350 bps lower than when the business was half the size in sales terms. Management is confident that its scale will help it to rebuild the gross over time. There’s no doubt that management is pursuing the right policy in winning as much shortterm market share as it can and not giving up its competitive position. The problem is that the irrational pricing behaviour is persisting longer than expected.

Excel Developer Its midday, so I'll just sneak some DPL in, https://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/markets/article-6556963/House-price-growth-slows-dramatically-weakest-level-nearly-six-years-index-finds.html
BE12:00pm

So, whilst the sales line is actually rising, we have to take
action on the bottom line as the gross margin and the cost base is not behaving, and won’t evolve in the way that we expected. In EBITDA terms, forecasts of £5.0m, £7.2m and £9.3m have become £3.2m (-36%), £4.9m (-32%) and £8m (-14%) and the downgrade to PBT are more severe (law of small numbers): £2.6m becomes £0.8m (-69%), £4.6m is now £2.3m (halving) and £6.3m is now £5m (-21%). It is difficult to see the shares coping terribly well with the downgrades, even if the policy of prioritising winning market share is well known, and it may take a couple of solid earnings prints to reassure investors that the margin picture has truly stabilised. There’s a really good company here though, winning market share and appealing to customers: the long term picture is highly positive.

Blank canvas thanks BE for everything today. Thanks also to Fatdaz
FATDAZ re the nationwide stats someone flagged on Twitter that regional stats dint tally with or add up to national totals ?

Music kit seems to be the kind of thing that doesn't need to arrive immediately and will, for the casual buyer, not need the reassurance of a known brand name.

In many respects the strength of the sales line should carry all, and it’s clear that G4M is resonating with customers better than ever. However, the persistence of the pricing competition will concern investors, and with big downgrades to the bottom line today it may take a while for the shares to regain their poise. From Buy to HOLD.
